instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP1V8_S5: What is PP1V8_S5? PP1V8_S5 is a 1.8v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state. .
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 16" MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
Hi, just this device came in

20V draw with batterie 

no dong, no display


checked the power sequenz from repair wiki
[URL unfurl="true"]https://repair.wiki/w/A2141_2019_16%22_MacBook_Pro[/URL]

<SIGNAL>PMU_CLK32K_PCH</SIGNAL> is ok
<SIGNAL>PMU_ACTIVE_READY</SIGNAL> is 1.8V
<SIGNAL>PMU_ONOF_L</SIGNAL> is 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V

<RESISTOR>R8013</RESISTOR> Pin1 has a nice sinus wave

so it seems me the problem could be the PMU, what do you think?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 16" MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
Any history available?

Be aware, this machine requires 96, or 140W charger.
Do you get expected SLPS2R and AWAKE voltages?
It is recognized into DFU?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 16" MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> dont turn on
threads.message:
I use a laboratory power supply , until now that was good for all <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>    1.81V
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>    1.11V
<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>    0.81V

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL>    1.8V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>     3.36V
PPVDDCPUSRAM_AWAKE    0.81V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL>   1.21V

the history is it stopped from one day top the other

I was sure that I had tried a recognition in DFU mode. Now, for the sake of order, I tried it again and how cool, it says RECOVERY on the display. Then I carried out all the necessary steps. The case can be closed. The problem has been solved.

Thanks to 2informations that I had not yet desoldered the PMU.
